text.para: There may be times when you want to specify a type on to a variable. This can be done with casting. Python is an object-orientated language, and as such it uses classes to define data types, including its primitive types.

list.li_title: Casting in python is therefore done using constructor functions:
list.item: int() - constructs an integer number from an integer literal, a float literal (by removing all decimals), or a string literal (providing the string represents a whole number)
float() - constructs a float number from an integer literal, a float literal or a string literal (providing the string represents a float or an integer)
str() - constructs a string from a wide variety of data types, including strings, integer literals and float literals

editor.title: Example
editor.syntax: x = int(2.8) # x will be 2 y = float(1) # y will be 1.0 z = str(3.0) # z will be '3.0'
